abstract:
Two-player, zero-sum games of infinite duration and their quantitative
versions are often used in verification to model the interaction between a
controller (Eve) and an antagonistic environment (Adam). The question usually
addressed is that of the existence (and computability) of a strategy for Eve
that can maximize her payoff against any strategy of Adam. In this work we are
interested in strategies of Eve that minimize her regret. That is to say, we
are interested in finding a strategy that minimizes the difference between her
actual payoff and the payoff she could have achieved if she had known the
strategy of Adam in advance. We give algorithms to compute the strategies of
Eve that ensure minimal regret against an adversary whose choice of strategy is
(i) unrestricted, (ii) limited to positional strategies, or (iii) limited to
word strategies. We also establish relations between the latter version and
other problems studied in the literature.
